awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Robust aquatic habitat representation for water resources decision-making
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET 1653452 PI:  Null, Sarah  
 
There is a pressing need for innovation in the incorporation of environmental objectives in water resources systems modeling. A promising path is to test aquatic habitat accuracy as complexity increases, and analyze if more complex models lead to more robust water resources decision-making to incorporate effectively environmental objectives into water resources systems modeling. This project will advance representation of aquatic habitat in water resources systems modeling by enlarging the solution space to decisions beyond streamflow and reservoir releases. Evaluating aquatic habitat representation in water resources systems models with robust decision-making provides critical new paths toward stable water resources decision-making.   

Integrated research and education tasks are: 1) test the accuracy and generality of large spatial scale environmental data to represent aquatic habitat with varying levels of complexity, 2) quantify the robustness of aquatic habitat and hydro-economic tradeoffs in water resources systems models with uncertainty, and 3) expand public science literacy for water resources decision-making by integrating science with art. Because decisions between economic and environmental water use benefits largely rest on the values and preferences of the public, visual art communicates aquatic habitat complexity and the tradeoffs between economic and environmental water uses. This project aspires to reach an estimated 130,000 visitors with museum exhibits at the Natural History Museum of Utah and the Swaner EcoCenter to foster a scientifically-literate public.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to represent aquatic habitat with multiple environmental attributes to solve the problem of quantifying aquatic habitat in water resources system modeling for robust decision-making. Specific goals were to:

1)      Test the accuracy and generality of publicly-available, large spatial scale environmental data to represent aquatic habitat with varying levels of complexity.

2)      Quantify the robustness of aquatic habitat and hydro-economic tradeoffs in water resources systems models with uncertainty.

3)      Expand public science literacy for water resources decision-making by integrating science with art.

 

Broader Impact Outcomes

Museum Exhibit

I developed a water resources museum exhibit named Decisions Downstream, that combines art and science to educate the general public on future water development choices in Utah and how they will impact river habitats. It traveled to three venues throughout 2021 – 2022:

  • Utah Natural History Museum (Salt Lake City, UT) 
  • Utah State University (Logan, UT)
  • Swaner EcoCenter (Park City, UT)

My exhibit reached an estimated 130,000 visitors over 17 months, with 62% of surveyed visitors reported changing behavior or learning more about Utah rivers after visiting my exhibit.

Decisions Downstream was one of 25 exhibits in Think Water Utah, a statewide collaboration and conversation on the critical topic of water by Utah Humanities and its partners. Think Water Utah, with Decisions Downstream and other exhibits, was the 2022 recipient of the Outstanding Achievement Award from Utah Division of State History.

Workshops, Classroom Education, and Graduate Training

  • A habitat modeling workshop was led for the Utah Division of Wildlife Resources in 2022. The workshop taught participants to access and visualize modeled aquatic habitat data, and use the temperature model, habitat suitability, and model evaluation code from Goodrum & Null, 2023 (25 participants).
  • I taught approximately 620 Utah State University students fundamentals of representing habitat objectives in water management models in classroom courses.
  • Three graduate Theses and Dissertations:
  • Goodrum, Gregory C. 2020. Improving Aquatic habitat representation in Utah using large spatial scale environmental datasets. Utah State University. MS in Watershed Sciences.
  • Turney, Eryn K. 2023. Comparing commonly used aquatic habitat modeling methods for native fishes. Utah State University. MS in Ecology.
  • Goodrum, Gregory C. Aquatic habitat representation for robust water resources management and fish conservation decision-making. Utah State University. PhD in Watershed Sciences anticipated 2024.

 

Intellectual Merit Outcomes

Highlights

  • Morrisett et al. (2023) demonstrated that a diversion reduced flows downstream of a streamflow gaging site used to manage instream flows. The instream flow target location and volume were changed, resulting in more consistent suitable fish habitat and increasing end-of-year reservoir carryover in Idaho’s Island Park Reservoir.
  • Null and Wurtsbaugh (2020) analyzed the effects of water development for Utah’s Great Salt Lake level, salinity, and biology. Potential solutions to reduce consumptive water uses to stabilize Great Salt Lake level include water conservation projected to cost $14-96 million, water markets projected to cost $6-48 million, and a future water supply dam projected to cost $1.5 billion. With Wurtsbaugh et al. (2017), this research has been referenced by the Utah Legislature, forming the impetus for the state legislature to advance a 2022 $40 million Great Salt Lake restoration bill.
  • Kraft et al. (2019) developed a generalizable model to prioritize instream barrier removal to connect Bonneville Cutthroat Trout habitat, while maintaining human water uses in Utah’s Weber watershed. Removing 54 small instream barriers like road crossings, culverts, and diversion dams could reconnect about 160 km of suitable habitat and cost approximately $10 million. Our model quickly prioritized barrier removals that are currently being considered in the Weber Basin, lending scientific credibility to restoration decision-making.

Major Findings

  • Goodrum and Null (2023) estimated mean monthly aquatic habitat suitability throughout Utah for Bonneville Cutthroat Trout and Bluehead Sucker with publicly available, geospatial datasets. Simple models with predictors like stream temperature, gradient, and discharge outperformed more complex models and those that used only streamflow to characterize aquatic habitat.
  • Ficklin et al. (2022) estimated hydrologic intensification for major water resources basins around the world. We related changes to water demands for urban, agricultural, and threatened and endangered species to highlight where and how traditional water management approaches should be revisited to address hydrologic intensification.
  • Null et al. (2021) evaluated the mathematical properties of optimized tradeoffs to identify promising regions for compromise, suggest strategies for reducing conflicts, and better understand whether decision-makers are more or less likely to cooperate on environmental water allocations. This work takes a conceptual approach to understanding how to facilitate compromise among water uses based on the shape of tradeoff curves.
  • Génova et al (2018) demonstrated that an efficient allocation of water for instream uses requires quantifying the benefits obtained from those uses, so that tradeoffs between instream and offstream water uses can be considered. This study developed a generalizable, hybrid economic–engineering method to assess tradeoffs between competing instream and offstream uses.
